Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: You see a coworker about to walk under a suspended load, and you must shout to warn them instantly.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was sweeping up the debris near the crane. It was Jamie, texting, “Ugh, today’s dragging. Wish I could just talk to someone.” I knew he needed me to listen, to be the friend who always replied right away, who made him feel heard. I started typing a quick response, trying to sound supportive, but out of the corner of my eye, I saw Mike heading straight for the area under the suspended beam. My heart pounded. I was supposed to keep the site safe, to speak up immediately if I saw something dangerous. But if I shouted now, Jamie’s message would go unanswered, and he’d feel ignored—again. My thumb hovered over the send button, my mouth already open to yell. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing down, each demanding something I couldn’t give at the same time.
